text.p: The following are top headlines from selected Canadian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- U.S. launches second attack on Iraq: Clinton defends missile strikes against Hussein for incursion into northern region of country.

- Witness balks in stowaway case: Filipino sailor tells hearing for accused officers that his family has been threatened. A key witness in the extradition hearing of seven ship's officers accused of murdering Romanian stowaways refused to testify in a Halifax court yesterday.
- U.S. isolation weakens its hand: Resolution used to start action against Iraq vaguely written.
- Universities on trail of private money: With government support shrinking, privatization is a hot postsecondary issue.
- Golf wunderkind attracts fame and fortune: Tiger Woods hasn't won a professional tournament yet, but he has already become a superstar in the world of greens, sponsorships and television.
- Iraq strike spurs oil-price surge: U.S. attack sets stage for buoyant prices, higher profits and royalties for the rest of the year.
- Cancelled contracts cost Ottawa millions: Concern over large computer deals prompts policy to keep within budget.
- Potash Corp building empire: Shareholders set to gain, but farmers worry about prices.
- Computer buyers in New Brunswick granted tax break: Government wants a PC in every home.
- One master seen for brokers: Toronto Stock Exchange wants out of the broker regulation business and the Investment Dealers Association is willing to take it on, perhaps on a national scale.
- Potash Corp's US$1 billion Arcadian buy spurs anxiety, applause. -- Reuters Toronto Bureau 416 941-8100
